translations: when they want, they take away the stone, one of those stones, when the first work had been over. After (the fire) had already gone out (the stones) remain in their place. (and
as it is. (In the latter case) They
take it apart, finally they take it apart, if it does not fall. They take away their (own) stones, when it is needed. (2018_07_01_01.2 Arkah, Old Houses:16)

Preterit.turoyo: qayəmġắlabeqḥīr, w naqqaḥzelanšrīṭmə-ḥḏoḏe 126; 92/22; šriṭ u=ḥawy-awo me-ʕalqḏole d-u=qašo w-azzéʕabər b-gawe d-u=ṣʕuno u=kurrəkḥəlleu=ḥawyanoi=ḥayyaṯegəšriṭo me bayn dam=mayei=kurfaṯe d dawṣo u=ḥolo
translations: ‘This snake untwined from the priest’s neck and crawled into the sandal’; 47/71
crawled from the water to bite the uncle’ (96:60).

Preterit.turoyo: Šriṭo i fanerayḏi. My sweater was undone (распутился). (İlyas p.c)
